contentrichtext.text: [[Image:Georgetown Station.jpg|thumb|right|Historic railway station in Georgetown, Delaware, located along track formerly used by the Queen Anne's Railroad]] The '''Queen Anneâ€™s Railroad''' was a [[railroad]] that ran from [[Love Point, Maryland]] to [[Lewes, Delaware]] and was connected to [[Baltimore, Maryland|Baltimore]] via [[ferry]]. The Queen Anne's Railroad [[railroad company|company]] was formed in Maryland in 1894, and received legislative authorization from Delaware in February 1895.<ref name="Archives">{{cite web| url=http://archives.delaware.gov/markers/sc/QUEEN%20ANNES%20RAILROAD%20SC%20116.shtml| title=Queen Anne's Railroad| publisher=State of Delaware, Delaware Public Archives| date=October 31, 2007}}</ref> The railroad's original western terminus was in [[Queenstown, Maryland]], and was moved via a {{convert|13|mi|adj=on}} extension to Love Point in 1902,<ref name=StevensvilleDepot>{{cite web| url=http://www.historicqac.org/sites/StTrain.htm| title=Stevensville Train Depot| publisher=Historic Sites Consortium of Queen Anne's County}}</ref> which shortened the ferry trip to Baltimore. The Queen Anne's Railroad Company began operating a summer-only Cape May Express between Queenstown, Maryland and Lewes, Delaware in 1901 with a connecting steamer to [[Cape May, New Jersey]]. The company owned and operated the Queen Anne's Ferry & Equipment Company which consisted of the steamers Endeavor, Queen Anne and Queen Caroline.<ref>[http://www.scripophily.net/quanracoma19.html Queen Anne's Railroad Company - Maryland 1902]. Scripophily.com advertisement for 1902 stock certificate. Retrieved 2010-06-08</ref> ==Towns served== The following towns were served by the Queen Anne's Railroad: {{columns |col1= *[[Love Point, Maryland]] *[[Stevensville, Maryland]] *[[Chester, Maryland]] *[[Queenstown, Maryland]] *[[Centreville, Maryland]] (via the Centreville Branch) |col2= *[[Queen Anne, Maryland]] *[[Sudlersville, Maryland]] *[[Hickman, Delaware]] *[[Adamsville, Delaware]] *[[Blanchard, Delaware]] *[[Greenwood, Delaware]] |col3= *[[Owens, Delaware]] *[[Ellendale, Delaware]] *[[Milton, Delaware]] *[[Whitesboro, Delaware]] *[[Lewes, Delaware]] *[[Georgetown, Delaware]] }} ==Current status== [[Image:StevensvilleMD TrainStation.jpg|150px|thumb|right|The [[Stevensville, Maryland|Stevensville]] Train Depot as it exists today]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:SVilleTrainStation.jpg|150px|thumb|right|The [[Sudlersville, Maryland|Sudlersville]] Train Station as it looks today. It now serves as a Town History Archive and Museum]] --> Through a complex series of acquisitions in 1905, Queen Anne's Railroad ceased to exist and its assets became the property of the Maryland, Delaware and Virginia Railway Company (MD&V), a subsidiary of the [[Pennsylvania Railroad]].<ref name="Archives" /><ref name="Parks">{{cite web|url=http://www.r2parks.net/B&E.html|title=History of the Baltimore and Eastern Railroad|author=Richard Parks|date=August 15, 2009|accessdate=July 15, 2011}}</ref> Much of the rairload's original track has been abandoned, but segments are still used for freight rail service by the [[Delaware Coast Line Railroad]]. In [[Queen Anne's County, Maryland]], a project has converted much of the railroad right-of-way into part of the [[Cross Island Trail]], a [[rail trail]] which is in turn part of the [[American Discovery Trail]]. The path of the railroad is approximated today by the following roads: *[[Maryland Route 18]] *[[U.S. Route 50 in Maryland|U.S. Route 50]] *[[Maryland Route 404]] *[[Maryland Route 16]] *[[Delaware Route 16]] *[[Delaware Route 1]] *[[U.S. Route 9 in Delaware|U.S. Route 9]]. A Delaware state historical marker in Milton and another in Ellendale's historic Railroad Square district commemorate the railroad. The original railroad stations in Stevensville and Sudlersville are both still in existence and serve as museums.<ref name=StevensvilleDepot /><!-- [http://www.abc2news.com/news/state/story.aspx?content_id=f0b65d66-a0d3-4924-8253-8c7e33d06f59] dead link 2008-10-23 --> == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Queen Anne's Railroad}} [[Category:Defunct Maryland railroads]] [[Category:Defunct Delaware railroads]] [[Category:Predecessors of the Pennsylvania Railroad]] [[Category:Queen Anne's County, Maryland]] [[Category:Talbot County, Maryland]] [[Category:Caroline County, Maryland]] [[Category:Transportation in Sussex County, Delaware]] [[Category:Railway companies established in 1894]] [[Category:Railway companies disestablished in 1905]]
